passages.text: China (PRC) | Technology
AI/Cloud Capex: China quickly Catching up with US

In the past 12 months, the four Chinese CSPs' capex is \(\sim\) US\$45bn, vs US \(\)291bn\(at US peers. However, China is catching up quickly: 1) since 4Q23, China's capex has been growing faster every Q - by as much as 3x in 2Q25; 2) since 4Q24, China's capex to cloud rev ratio has exceeded that of the US; and 3) China's capex to total rev has been rising faster, though still below that of the US. Our top picks remain VNET/GDS. GDS REIT is trading at 24.5x EV/EBITDA.

China catching up quickly with the US in AI/cloud capex trends. For 2Q25, only Tencent reported a QoQ fall in capex among BAT (B=Baidu, A = Alibaba, T = Tencent). BABA/Baidu reported \(57\% /30\%\) QoQ capex growth. We previously highlighted 2Q25 cloud capex may not be exciting as our industry checks suggested large CSPs focused on securing chip supply from the GPU rental market in 2Q (following the US ban on H20). However, we think some CSPs chose to secure supply in the GPU rental market by buying the chips from renters instead of renting. That is likely why there was surprisingly strong capex growth of \(168\%\) at BAT in 2Q, vs \(100\%\) growth in 1Q. China's CSP capex has been on a structural and accelerating growth trend since 1Q23 (Chart 1), driven by both AI and Internet business volume growth. BABA has been the biggest growth driver (Chart 2). We also highlight that capex growth is driven not only by AI, as shown by strong demand for general servers, as seen in ZTE's 1H25 results.

China has already overtaken US in CSP capex to cloud rev ratio. Although China's absolute CSP capex (incl our est for Bytedance at around US \(14bn\) ) in the last 12 months is only \(15\%\) of that of its US peers, its capex to cloud rev ratio has exceeded that of the US since 4Q24 (Chart 4). In 2Q25, China's ratio was at \(121\%\) vs the US at \(94\%\) . That indicates Chinese CSPs are likely becoming even more aggressive than their US peers in AI/cloud capex. On the other hand, Chinese CSPs' capex to total rev ratio is still much lower than that of the US, but has been rising more rapidly (Chart 5). The likely reason for the discrepancy in these two ratios is that the US CSPs have massive cloud revenue (from both the US and RoW) vs the Chinese CSPs. For BAT, cloud accounted for only \(11\%\) of their total rev, vs \(20\%\) for the three US CSPs combined. Moreover, we believe the 3 Chinese CSPs have been aggressively pursuing AI capex to improve their core businesses, instead of for their 3rd-party enterprise customers in cloud. Thus, investors may be able to see rapid improvement in these CSPs' core business in the next year or two due to AI deployment.

China's much lower but rapidly rising capex could drive faster downstream AI adoption. We see 3 reasons why China's AI capex is lower than the US: 1) Chinese CSPs rev size is much smaller, given constraints in overseas expansion due to geopolitics; 2) bigger focus on profitability since the gov stepped up regulations in 2021; and 3) US chip restrictions (this is the least of the 3 reasons, in our view). But lower investment and focus on commercialization/ profitability likely will drive faster AI adoption, since AI applications thus developed would not have to be priced high for both enterprises and consumers. China is also forced to focus on compute efficiency (e.g., DeepSeek), and does not have power shortages or high power costs.

VNET/GDS still biggest beneficiaries. These remain our top picks. Note, GDS' China REIT has risen \(39\%\) since its IPO, and now trades at 24.5x 2026E EV/EBITDA (Range Technology's REIT at 22x), vs 10x/12x for VNET/GDS China. In addition to a growth story, both stocks have significant asset monetization opportunities in the next three years via sale of assets into their REIT vehicles.
Chart 1 - BAT Total Capex YoY Growth
Chart 2 - Alibaba Capex YoY Growth
Chart 3 - US vs. CN Cloud Capex YoY Growth
Chart 4 - Combined Cloud Capex to Cloud Rev Ratio - BAT vs AGM
Source: Company, Jefferies
Chart 5 - Combined Capex to Sales Ratio - BAT vs AGM
Source: Company, Jefferies

For Important Disclosure information on companies recommended in this report, please visit our website at https://javatar.bluematrix.com/ sellside/Disclosures.action or call 212.284.2300.

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price
Monitor- Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies' methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
